text: ਰਾਗੁ ਮਾਰੂ ਬਾਣੀ ਕਬੀਰ ਜੀਉ ਕੀ
section: Maru - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: Raag Maaroo, The Word Of Kabeer Jee:

transliteration.text: rāg mārū bānī kabīr jīu kī

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: None
author.description: There is no author associated with this line, as it may be the preamble to the hymn

section: Maru - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: One Universal Creator God. By The Grace Of The True Guru:

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: None
author.description: There is no author associated with this line, as it may be the preamble to the hymn

section: Maru - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: No one has seen the Fearless Lord, O renunciate.

melody.description: Maru was traditionally sung on the battlefield in preparation for war. This Raag has an aggressive nature, which creates an inner strength and power to express and emphasise the truth, regardless of the consequences. Maru’s nature conveys the fearlessness and strength that ensures the truth is spoken, no matter what the cost.

author.author: Saint Kabir
author.description:
Saint Kabir [1440 - 1518] was a Muslim mystic born in Varanasi in India, whose 541 hymns are included in the Guru Granth Sahib. His writings about God are full of love and devotion, very direct and striking in appeal.

The birth of Kabir remains to this day shrouded in mystery and legend. Authorities disagree on both when he was born and who his parents were. One legend proclaims a divine virginal birth. His mother was reputed to have been of the Brahman caste and to have become pregnant after a visit to a Hindu shrine.

Because she was unwed, she abandoned Kabir, who was found and adopted by a Muslim weaver. That his early life began as a Muslim there is no doubt, although he later became influenced by the Hindu ascetic, Ramananda, who he accepted as his Guru.

section: Maru - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: Without the Fear of God, how can the Fearless Lord be obtained? ||1||

melody.description: Maru was traditionally sung on the battlefield in preparation for war. This Raag has an aggressive nature, which creates an inner strength and power to express and emphasise the truth, regardless of the consequences. Maru’s nature conveys the fearlessness and strength that ensures the truth is spoken, no matter what the cost.

author.author: Saint Kabir
author.description:
Saint Kabir [1440 - 1518] was a Muslim mystic born in Varanasi in India, whose 541 hymns are included in the Guru Granth Sahib. His writings about God are full of love and devotion, very direct and striking in appeal.

The birth of Kabir remains to this day shrouded in mystery and legend. Authorities disagree on both when he was born and who his parents were. One legend proclaims a divine virginal birth. text: ਸਹੁ ਹਦੂਰਿ ਦੇਖੈ ਤਾਂ ਭਉ ਪਵੈ ਬੈਰਾਗੀਅੜੇ ॥
section: Maru - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: If one sees the Presence of his Husband Lord near at hand, then he feels the Fear of God, O renunciate.

transliteration.text: sah hadūr dēkhai tānh bhau pavai bairāgīarē .

melody.description: Maru was traditionally sung on the battlefield in preparation for war. This Raag has an aggressive nature, which creates an inner strength and power to express and emphasise the truth, regardless of the consequences. Maru’s nature conveys the fearlessness and strength that ensures the truth is spoken, no matter what the cost.

text: ਹੁਕਮੈ ਬੂਝੈ ਤ ਨਿਰਭਉ ਹੋਇ ਵਣਾਹੰਬੈ ॥੨॥
section: Maru - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: If he realizes the Hukam of the Lord's Command, then he becomes fearless. ||2||

transliteration.text: hukamai būjhai t nirabhau hōi vanāhanbai .2.

melody.description: Maru was traditionally sung on the battlefield in preparation for war. This Raag has an aggressive nature, which creates an inner strength and power to express and emphasise the truth, regardless of the consequences. Maru’s nature conveys the fearlessness and strength that ensures the truth is spoken, no matter what the cost.

section: Maru - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: Don't practice hypocrisy with the Lord, O renunciate!

melody.description: Maru was traditionally sung on the battlefield in preparation for war. This Raag has an aggressive nature, which creates an inner strength and power to express and emphasise the truth, regardless of the consequences. Maru’s nature conveys the fearlessness and strength that ensures the truth is spoken, no matter what the cost.

section: Maru - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: The whole world is filled with hypocrisy. ||3||

Maru’s nature conveys the fearlessness and strength that ensures the truth is spoken, no matter what the cost.

section: Maru - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: Thirst and desire do not just go away, O renunciate.

melody.description: Maru was traditionally sung on the battlefield in preparation for war. This Raag has an aggressive nature, which creates an inner strength and power to express and emphasise the truth, regardless of the consequences. Maru’s nature conveys the fearlessness and strength that ensures the truth is spoken, no matter what the cost.

section: Maru - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: The body is burning in the fire of worldly love and attachment. ||4||

translation.text: Anxiety is burned, and the body is burned, O renunciate,

translation.text: only if one lets his mind become dead. ||5||

text: ਸਤਿਗੁਰ ਬਿਨੁ ਬੈਰਾਗੁ ਨ ਹੋਵਈ ਬੈਰਾਗੀਅੜੇ ॥
section: Maru - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: Without the True Guru, there can be no renunciation,

transliteration.text: satigur bin bairāg n hōvaī bairāgīarē .

This Raag has an aggressive nature, which creates an inner strength and power to express and emphasise the truth, regardless of the consequences. translation.text: Says Kabeer, I offer this one prayer, O renunciate.

text: ਮੋ ਕਉ ਭਉਜਲੁ ਪਾਰਿ ਉਤਾਰਿ ਵਣਾਹੰਬੈ ॥੮॥੧॥੮॥
section: Maru - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: Carry me across the terrifying world-ocean. ||8||1||8||

transliteration.text: mō kau bhaujal pār utār vanāhanbai .8.1.8.

melody.description: Maru was traditionally sung on the battlefield in preparation for war.
